title: Facebook vs. Twitter on political ads: What Zuckerberg said, how Dorsey responded
text:
Twitter's announcement Wednesday that it will ban political and issues advertising added a new level of friction to its long-running rivalry with Facebook, which has faced more than a month of blowback for refusing to penalize candidates for lying in their ads.

The move came a week after Facebook founder and CEO Mark Zuckerberg suffered a grilling on Capitol Hill, especially from Democrats, over his company’s disinterest in insisting on truthfulness in political advertising — adding to its problems in Washington as it faces a possible antitrust probe and criticism about its handling of users' data.

Story Continued Below

In announcing the new policy, Twitter CEO Jack Dorsey took a few apparent shots at the arguments Zuckerberg and others have made for allowing deceptive political ads. In a speech Oct. 17 at Georgetown University, Zuckerberg framed the issue as one of "free expression" and letting voters, not tech companies, judge politicians' arguments. But Dorsey said it's a matter of protecting democracy in the face of the internet's "increasing velocity, sophistication, and overwhelming scale."
